dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we see him. WILLY LUMP LUMP looks right at us. His is a face one does forget. A face that inspires...articles, novels, movies. the one we’re about to see.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LUMP LUMP
dialogues.text: .-.I fucken love robbing banks. Unfortunately for me, it happens to be illegal. That’s why I’m sitting here talking to you. Kinda a bummer, but then again, whatever... A TITLE reads, “Federal Correctional Institute, Terminal Island. San Pedro, California.” WILLY LUMP LUMP (CONT’D) There are 5 rules to robbing a bank. And that’s the first rule. Do it for the love. For the doing of the thing. Make it your masterpiece. Like Ali, Ludwig Van, Musashi, Plato, Da Vinci. Make it your Rumble in the Jungle, your 9th, your Samurai Sword, your Apology, your Mona Lisa... Don’t do it for the money. Or because you’re pissed off at the world and you wanna do the whole bullshit whoop de whoop gangster thing, and you wanna shoot somebody. Like those whack job amateurs in North Hollywood. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WILLY LUMP LUMP (CONT’D) They had it going good for a while, but then they fucked it all up because they wanted to shoot it out with the cops, because they probably couldn’t get any ass and had small cocks. If mommy didn’t treat you good, go start a fire or some shit. But don’t rob a bank... Willy takes a sip of his piping hot coffee. The coffee mu metal, and small. He wears an orange jumpsuit emblazoned black, faded block letters across it that read “FCI”. In the unseen surrounding environs, the cold, reverberant hollow SOUNDS OF PRISON can be heard. WILLY LUMP LUMP (CONT’D) Second rule, don’t do chump change. Whether you steal 1 dollar, or 100 million, the length of your visit to Hotel Federal Prison will be the same. So when you pick your score, make sure it don’t come with fries and a shake. Make sure it’s so much goddamn money, stuffing it in your pockets ain’t an option... The third rule, once you got the money, don’t spend it. Because remember, you didn’t do it for the money. And if you spend it, you'll run out. And if you run out, you'll become a junkie. Because you’1l1 want more. And if you want more, you'll make mistakes... Junkies come in all shapes and sizes, not all of them Crack Ho's... Willy takes a drag from a cig. Doesn’t bother ashing. Old diffused tats dot his forearms. The thick black-rimmed glasses he wears, “Mafias”, ID him as a convict of high standing. WILLY LUMP LUMP (CONT’D) The fourth rule. Prepare for the worst. Because if shit don’t go according to plan, which it won’t, and drama starts popping off, which it will, you better be down for the get down, homeboy... Willy finally exhales. The VOICE of a younger man we do n see, asks Willy the same question some of you may have.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: What’s the last rule? You said 5. Willy crunches his eyes, holds his hand up, annoyed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 3.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LUMP LUMP
dialogues.text: You in some sort of a rush? The voice doesn’t respond. Willy takes another sip of his coffee, savors it. In a rush, Willy isn’t. WILLY LUMP LUMP (CONT’D) The last rule. Willy takes a long drag from his cig, then exhales slowly WILLY LUMP LUMP (CONT’D) When you get caught, honky... (waves cig back and forth while slowly shaking his head) No sharing showers... Then gesticulates for emphasis by jutting the cig at our face. WILLY LUMP LUMP (CONT’D) Push flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High above the Los Angeles basin. So high, the city sprea out below us like the Thomas Guide. CAMERA PUSHES DOWN ON the VAPOR LIGHTS that line endless boulevards. On the horizon, dawn approaches. A TITLE reads, “2400 times a year. 44 times a week. 9 tim day. Every 48 minutes, a bank is robbed here... This is t real bank-robbery capital of the world..." Only a few vehicles out this time of day. COME IN ON one them -- A BRINKS ARMORED TRUCK. It winds the barren stree TITLE reads, “Los Angeles”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four Brinks employees inside. Two up front -- DRIVER, driving, and MESSENGER, riding shotgun. The HOPPER and th SWAMPER in back. Nextel radios perched atop their shoulde Sidearms issued to all. An AR-15 CARBINE slotted up front Nobody talks. Too early for that. The Driver struggles to keep his eyes open. He starts to nod off, when the truck swerves. Messenger hits his arm. Driver's eyes snap back open. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 4.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Shit. Sorry. The Armored Truck pulls into a parking lot. Messenger and Swamper hop out. Driver and Hopper remain in the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TITLE reads, “Gardena. 5:14 am”. The only sound heard i that of the TRUCK’S ENGINE IDLING. ARMORED TRUCK’S POV -- Messenger and Swamper order, pay t KOREAN GUY behind the counter inside. ON DRIVER -- staring blankly ahead. Messenger and Swamper exit, coffees and boxes of donuts in hand. Quiet still. Driver’s hand reaches for the “unlock” button. ON MESSENGER -- 10 feet from the Armored, hands full. Ano morning, another donut run. Same as every other day. Almo SOUNDS approach. ENGINES. Driver's hand pauses just above unlock button.

dialogues.speaker: TO THE FRONT AND REAR OF THE ARMORED, BLOCKING IT IN.
dialogues.text: DOORS FLY OPEN AND MEN EMERGE -- 1 from the front SUV and from the rear, their bodies covered in black BDUs and KEV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and HK ASSAULT RIFLES at the Brinks guys. These OUTLAWS m in a precise military like fashion, covering fields of fi ON MESSENGER -- literally frozen in indecision. Tension racking his body, HIS HAND GRIPS HIS JUMBO COFFEE TOO TIG His eyes go to the SIDEARM on his belt. Albeit unfortunat occasions like these do fit within the particulars of his description. He’s supposed to do something here. But can’ ON DRIVER -- fumbling with his nextel, frantic, can’t get words out fast enough -

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (into nextel) -3170!! WE’RE BEING HELD UP BEING HELD UP- Hits a 911 BEACON in the dash, then suddenly can’t speak anymore as a monster of a man, OUTLAW#1, RUSHES HIM, JUMP ONTO THE HOOD of the Armored. ON OUTLAWS#2 and #3 -- rushing Messenger and Swamper, bar aimed right at their heads. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 5.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON MESSENGER -- hand about to crush his piping hot coffee

dialogues.speaker: DON'T FUCKING MOVE
dialogues.text: HOUR! IT ISN’T WORTH IT!

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: (to trembling Messenger) Relax homes, we’re not here for you. ON DRIVER -- looking up at Outlaw#l AIMING AN HK-416 RIGH HIM through the “bulletproof” window. God does he hope it

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: (muffled by the gas-mask)

dialogues.speaker: ARMOR-PIERCING ROUNDS ARE CHAMBERED IN
dialogues.text: THIS FIREARM. DO NOT BE THE IDIOT THAT’S

dialogues.speaker: THE UNLOCK AND STEP AWAY FROM THE TRUCK
dialogues.text: Driver hesitates, quivering, foot an inch above the gas pedal. OUTLAW#1 (CONT’D) FUCKING DO IT!! Now!! ON MESSENGER -- hand shaking violently, when he involunta CRUSHES THE CUP OF COFFEE. The steaming hot liquid SPILLS OVER HIS HAND and leg. HE SCREAMS IN PAIN and makes an untimely flinching motion-- BOOM. Outlaw#2 doesn’t hesitate. Messenger’s shoulder and neck are blown apart. He drops. Donuts spill. Swamper horrors.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER PUNCHES IT. SLAMS INTO THE FRONT SUV, GRINDS IT
dialogues.text: FORWARD. OUTLAW#1 LURCHES FORWARD FROM IMPACT, spills ont the Armored’s roof. He grabs for anything to hold on to. ON OUTLAW DRIVER -- in the front SUV, trying in vain to p off. The Armored is too powerful. ON OUTLAW#1 -- pulls himself back onto the hood. Gains balance. AIMS THE HK INTO THE WINDSHIELD AND UNLOADS. The high-pitched rounds are deafening. THE WINDSHIELD AND DRI ARE OBLITERATED. ON OUTLAW#2 -- bringing the butt of his shotgun across Swamper’s jaw. Swamper collapses. OUTLAW DRIVER hops out of the SUV with a SLEDGEHAMMER. He jumps onto the Armored’s hood and SWINGS IT INTO THE ARMO TRUCK’S WINDSHIELD, CAVING THE WINDSHIELD IN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 6.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GUNSHOTS are fired from within the Armored -- Hopper. Outlaw#1 tosses in a FLASHBANG. A BLAST of LIGHT and SOUN

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: (to Outlaw Driver) Get in get in!! Outlaw Driver slips through the windshield into the cab. “unlock”, PUSHES OUT THE BODY OF THE DRIVER. Outlaws#2 and #3 rush the rear of the Armored, RIP OPEN T REAR DOORS. SMOKE BILLOWS out of the Armored. Inside, Hopper’s ears bleed. He chokes violently. Outlaw#1 hops in the Armored passenger seat. Outlaw Drive throws the Armored into gear. As Outlaw#2 drags Hopper out onto the pavement, 3 GARDENA CRUISERS squeal to a halt in the middle of the street, 50 meters back. Doors swing open. UNIFORMED GARDENA COPS OPE FIRE WITH THEIR .9MM SIDEARMS. The rounds ping off of the Armored and pavement. OUTLAW#2

dialogues.speaker: SPINS TOWARD THE COPS, DROPS TO A SEATED-FIRING POSITION,
dialogues.text: OPENS FIRE. Outlaw#3 drops his shotgun, presents his .45, UNLOADS HIS CLIP. Their HK rounds are deadly accurate, ripping thru the Gardena PD Cruiser’s doors, DROPPING 1 C Outgunned, the cops ball up for cover, don’t return fire.

dialogues.speaker: LETS GO LETS GO LETS GO
dialogues.text: Outlaw#2 and #3 sprint for the SUV while the Cop’s gunfir suppressed. Suddenly, 3, 4 SHERIFF’S DEPT CROWN VICS RESP ONTO THE SCENE, tires smoking as they brake to stops. COP JUMP OUT WITH AR-15 CARBINES, OPEN FIRE ON THE SUSPECTS.

dialogues.speaker: THEY GOT CARBINES
dialogues.text: The high-velocity rounds ricochet and TEAR INTO THE SUV.

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: INTO THE SUV. He drops, scream drowned out by gunfire. OUTLAW #1 (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: MOTHERFUCKER
dialogues.text: Outlaw#2 takes cover, desperate to reload, then returns f A BLIZZARD OF ZIPPING LEAD FILLS THE DAWN AIR.

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: I’M ALMOST OUT!!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 7.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: If something isn’t done fast, they’1ll never get out of h So Outlaw#1 flips his HK 416 onto “full-auto”, hops out o the Armored, WALKS DIRECTLY AT THE COPS, AND OPENS FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: THE CROWN VIC WINDSHIELDS AND HOODS. SHELL-CASINGS bounce off the street at his feet. A FEW ROUNDS THUMP INTO HIS BODY ARMOR, EXPELLING THE AIR FROM HIS LUNGS. Clip done, drops it out, rips a fresh clip off his torso, pops it in and repeats. All in one fluid motion. Empties the next clip. The Cops return fire no more, pressed into the pavement. Outlaw#1 turns, runs back in the Armored. Outlaw#2 TOSSES SMOKE GRENADES INTO THE STREET, clouds the Cops visual, cloaking their exfil, jumps into the SUV. BOTH THE ARMORE AND SUV PEEL AWAY FROM THE SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outlaw#1 rips off his gas mask.

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: How the fuck those chase cars here?!! This is RAY MERRIMEN, 38, and clearly the leader. His muscular neck and ferocious demeanor belie great intellig that can be seen in those hard, icy blue eyes. He’s very, very dangerous, yes. But not wild. Calculating. He keys a Nextel “push-to-talk” phone:

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: (into Nextel) Greenpeace, this is Repeat Offender. Need your eyes. Merrimen looks out the window, SCANS THE SKIES ABOVE.

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW DRIVER
dialogues.text: We clean?!

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: So far. Hug the airport, take the tunnel. Merrimen speaks into a MIC protruding from beneath the kevlar.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into chest mic) Lava, this is Repeat Offender. Pull off now!  10 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Armored and SUV barrel down the early morning streets 80+ mph. THE SUV BAILS OUT ONTO A SIDE-STREET. The Armored hits a hard right, ENTERS A TUNNEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SUV rolls to a quiet stop in a RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHO

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: WINDEX AND BABY-WIPES. POURS GASOLINE on the dash, steeri wheel and seats. Walks away from the SUV. He peels out a CAR-KEY TAPED TO HIS CHEST, quietly sticks into the door of a nondescript TOYOTA MINIVAN parked ther Hops in and drives off, unnoticed. In the distance, SIRENS can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROAR OF THE ARMORED’S ENGINE REVERBERATES throughout tunnel as they tear away from the scene, desperate to eva the response. Merrimen’s head is on a swivel clocking the streets. IN THE ARMORED -- they ROUND A CURVE in the tunnel. 95 mp The tunnel empties back onto the city streets.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: We're clean! INT. “PACIFIC HORIZON FREIGHT” 3PL WAREHOUSE / OFFICE - D BOSCO sits in a vast warehouse OFFICE, in front of a lapt READS THEIR “SIGNATURE” ON THE DATONG SYSTEM THAT DISPLAY

dialogues.speaker: LIVE MAP-GRID FEED OF THE STREETS, ALL COP CARS AND THEIR
dialogues.text: EXACT LOCATION DISPLAYED. Bosco keys a radio, guides them through the gauntlet of responding cops.

dialogues.speaker: BOSCO
dialogues.text: (into radio) Go right on Doty, right on Doty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outlaw Driver follows Bosco’s directions. THEY STOP IN AN

dialogues.speaker: TENSION. THEY DRIVE THE LAST FEW BLOCKS TO THE SAFETY OF.
dialogues.text: 11 12 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 9. EXT. “THIRD WORLD” INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT, WILMINGTON —- DAW A sea of BUSINESS PARKS, industrial warehouses, refinerie tank-farms all divided by pot-holed streets. The VINCENT THOMAS BRIDGE looms overhead. A coyote scurries as the Armored approaches. It backs into one of the warehouses. INT. “PACIFIC HORIZON FREIGHT” 3PL WAREHOUSE - DAWN 12 Outlaw#2 and a TONGAN CARGO HARD shut the warehouse slidi doors. The Toyota Minivan already parked inside. Outlaw#2 hits several numbers on a SECURITY KEYPAD, securing the building. Beep-beeping SOUND as the Armored reverses in a parks. “Pacific Horizon Freight” is written on the warehouse wal few SAMOAN AND TONGAN DOCKWORKERS man the vast warehouse, home to a 3PL, “Third Party Logistics”, shipping-freight The Outlaws are exhausted. No one speaks as they strip of kevlar, gas masks, body armor, the mood tense. Around the stacks of empty pallets, shrink-wrapped freight, forklift high-tech security equipment, radios, stripped cars, gas cans, pvc piping, highway flares, a weight bench... Fluorescents buzz 28ft overhead, giving us our FIRST CLEA

dialogues.speaker: GLIMPSE OF THIS ARMED ROBBERY CREW
dialogues.text: Seen before, MERRIMEN, the leader. Outlaw#2 pulls off his gear, revealing ENSON LEVOUX. Fier fat, big, Samoan. With corn-rows. Merrimen’s “lieutenant” Their laptop Datong navigator, BO “BOSCO” OSTROMAN, 42. A barrel-chested whiteboy from Huntington. “PENI” ink besid some faded military tat on his thick arms. Lastly, the Outlaw Driver, DONNIE ALISON, 33, edgy white quiet-type, which are usually the most dangerous, just no this case. They don’t come much more intimidating than th Everyone wears SURGICAL GLOVES when handling the Armored.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: Checked for trackers? (Enson nods “of course”) Do it again. Enson slips beneath the truck’s underbelly, sweeps the en chassis and engine with a FREQUENCY SCANNER.

dialogues.speaker: ENSON
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s one of the old models. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 10.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donnie stands over a garbage can and PUKES. He looks at h hands -- still shaking with adrenaline.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: (to Bosco) And you were clean? (Bosco shrugs, looks to Enson) I asked you. Not him. Were you?

dialogues.speaker: BOSCO
dialogues.text: -yeah. Ran figure 8’s. No fleas... Merrimen’s eyes burn into Bosco. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t we know about the chase cars? How did the call get through-

dialogues.speaker: ENSON
dialogues.text: —-Ray. All heads turn to Enson. No one usually speaks when Merri is this hot, because it just doesn’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: ENSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We knew the risks. Shit popped off. We handled it... That’s it. Merrimen doesn’t respond. Then to Bosco:

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: Get back over there, see who responded. Probably LASD. They’1ll supercede Gardena... If it’s Major Crimes, we got a problem. Bosco pulls on a hoodie, grabs a DIGITAL CAMERA, and leav Merrimen and Donnie turn their attention to the Armored Truck. Bulletholes riddle it’s sides. Donnie shuts off th engine. Merrimen runs his hands over the bulletholes:

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Patch these up. Need it like new. Donnie nods. Merrimen circles the truck, inspecting it thoroughly. He stops behind the rear doors. Pops open the latches, and swings open the doors. Inside... NOTHING. It’s empty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 14 15 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 11.

dialogues.speaker: ENSON
dialogues.text: You good? Merrimen looks over the truck one last time. Nods:

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: «+. We’re cop killers now... His words hang in the air. HOLD ON HIM. TITLE reads, “Merrimen”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a PAIR OF EYES. They’re open really wide. And th pupils dilated. Black saucers. PULL BACK to reveal “BIG N FLANAGAN, 41, white, cock-strong muscles, the kind that c from genetics, not from doing a lot of reps on Cybex mach at Bally’s. He’s sporting a Rolex, a bit of bling, couple tats, got a shaved head a bushy ZZ-TOP style goatee, and bad skin that accompanies too many cycles of ‘roids. Nick dumps Visine in his eyes while driving. Fast. Zips through LA’s South Bay streets by braille, doesn’t bother even peeking at the road ahead. All windows are down. He breathes into his hand, checks his breath. Fumbles around glovebox for gum. Finds some, pops it in his mouth. He’s doing a decent job pulling himself together, despite the that he looks like he’s spent the last week on the dark s Nick dials down the radio as he turns onto a working-clas suburban residential street. Kills the lights and engine before coasting quietly into a driveway, parks. EXT. NICK’S HOUSE, REDONDO BEACH - DAWN 14 Nick takes his boots off, walks barefoot up to his house, single-story “modern” built in the 50's, typical of subur SoCal. Yet with nouveau upgrades -- fountains, marble col frame the front door, plexi-hoop court in back, and lots gangster’d-out land yachts parked on the lawn. INT. NICK’S HOUSE - DAWN 15 The jangle of keys. But they don’t work. Nick tries in va to open the back pantry door. Opts to jimmy open a window instead, crawls and squeezes his way through it. His clot catch and tear on something. He silently curses himself. Tip-toes into the kitchen. It’s quiet and dark. Only a fe night-lights on. The house is home to a family, as kids’ and baby stuff is scattered throughout. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nick gingerly opens the fridge, bends down to see what’s the menu when a CRASHING SOUND shatters the quiet. He cringes, squeezes his eyes shut. Then peeks down -- a HAN lies at his feet, fell out of his waistband. He carefully picks it up, sets it on the counter with wal and keys. Listens in the house. All remains quiet. Phew. He grabs a water, gulps it down while checking his cell. erases all “recent calls”, when he freezes. Gets a weird feeling someone's there. Turns his head, and gasps. A WOM SITS IN THE NEARBY DARK, WATCHING HIM. Nick clutches his chest, sighs in relief.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, babe, scared the shit out of me! I might’ve shot you. Can’t do that. His wife, DEBBIE, late 30s, once hot and sweet, now jaded sleep-deprived, sits with her legs and arms crossed, and hair-extensions balled up in a clip.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Can’t do what?

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Creep up on me like that.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You erase your recent calls? Nick starts to get nervous, scrambles.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Erase? What do you mean... (holds up his cell) The phone? I don’t know how to work this fucking thing, you know that - Debbie imitates him, repeats his line while grinding her and bouncing it back and forth just like him. Exactly lik him.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: “I don’t know how to work this fucking thing." Nick slumps back, sighs deeply, playing the victim.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Babe, we really have to do this right now — (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 13.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: -where you been? It’s 6am. (makes quotes with her fingers) “Work”? A surveillance? Robbing drug dealers? You smell like a stripper. Nick throws his hands up, at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. And I was out banging hookers... (incredulous) Of course I was at work! Debbie stands, fed up, walks up to him. She holds her cel his face. A TEXT MESSAGE is up on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh really? “That was SO hot"? Nick sees the text he sent. To his wife. At 5am. Whoops. doesn’t respond. He shifts, now crawling out of his skin, can’t come up with a story fast enough. DEBBIE (CONT’D) You used to have such tight game... Debbie shakes her head in disgust. Tears pool in her eyes

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feel so sorry for you. You pathetic, dope fiend whore. Debbie walks off in tears, disappears into the bedrooms. buries his face in his hands, rubs his temples. Take a de long, stressed breath. Shakes his head at himself. He notices 2 PACKED SUITCASES by the front door. Hears commotion in the bedrooms. His kids’ voices. Debbie is wa them up.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: (hushed, to himself) What the.... Debbie ushers their 2 daughters, McKENNA, 7, CASSADY, 3, the door. The girls are still half-asleep, teary and conf by what’s going on. Deb scoops Cassady up into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: ...it’s OK honey, we’re going to Auntie’s house. Daddy has to do some work to the house and it’1l be too loud for you guys. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 14.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nick tries to cut her off at the door, whispering to her. Deb can’t get them out of there fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Woah woah woah. Wifey, what are you doing?! Seriously - Debbie just blows right over any acknowledgement of what’ actually going down. She’s moving out, and taking the kid with her. And there’s nothing else to say about it.

dialogues.speaker: MCKENNA
dialogues.text: Is Daddy coming with us?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Daddy doesn’t have time for us right now.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Oh that’s good. Well said. (to McKenna) Mommy didn’t mean that. The situation is such that, Nick doesn’t know what the he to say, or do. All he knows is, it sucks.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t come right now sweetheart, but I‘1l see you a little later, OK? Come here- McKenna and Nick reach to hug one another, but Debbie gra McKenna’s hand and whisks her right out the door.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Deb, for Christ sake, can you slow it down a second?! Nope. Into the car they go, despite her daughter’s protes Debbie situates the girls in the car seats, then turns ba to the house to grab her bags. Nick walks beside her, tri to conceal from his girls the fact that he’s about to rip their mother’s head off.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hisses in a whisper) Have you lost your fucking mind, woman?! What the fuck?!

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh that’s nice, drop f-bombs in front of my daughters. Good fathering. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 15.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Debbie doesn’t bother keeping her voice down. As if she w her daughters to know her reality.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Shhhh! Quiet, Christ! (throws his hands up) “My”? What the -—

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: - gonna find me a man whose cock actually gets hard. Nick snaps an internal gasket. His face turns so red, it’ almost blue. But somehow, he keeps a lid on it. Debbie grabs her bags, rushes back to the car. Nick paces circles. He goes to his wife just before she gets into th car, reaches for her, pleading with her:

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Deb, stop. Seriously, please don’t do this - Debbie explodes with pent up pain, and unleashes on her husband. She punches and claws at him like a banshee. Nic just back-pedals and tries to evade her onslaught.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You motherfucker!!! STAY AWAY FROM ME!!!

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Nice job. Nice. Good stuff. Debbie screams, hysterical. Tears and upset stream down h face. As she jumps behind the wheel, both McKenna and Cas start balling. A marriage disintegrates, right before our eyes. BIG NICK (CONT’D) Perfect. The car’s tires chirp as Debbie throws it in reverse, the she punches it, and Nick’s family disappears down the str Nick stands there in his driveway, unmoving, staring into space, feeling like the world’s biggest asshole. Looks ar his property, eyes glazed over, like it’s an alien planet One of the neighbors, an OLD MAN IN A TRACKSUIT, comes ou his front door and mad-dogs Nick. Surely does not appreci nor approve of, the baby mama drama. Nick waves to him: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: 15 16 17 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 16.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BIG NICK (CONT’D) Morning. As Nick slowly walks back inside, a TITLE reads, “Big Nic

dialogues.text: Nick plops down on the couch. He feels the fresh scratche and welts on his face, pulls out his cell phone, checks t now infamous text. His eyes slowly look around at his kid toys, at the photo on the wall of he and Debbie all dolle on some beach in the islands. And his body goes numb. Nick sits there like that, alone, for a long, painful mom Then his cell vibrates. And vibrates. Finally, he checks Squints his eyes at the number. Answers.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Yip? Nick listens, doesn’t at all like what he’s hearing from other end. Then he hangs up. Nick shuts his eyes, and sighs, deep and long... EXT. RANDY’S DONUT SHOP, GARDENA - MORNING 17 A BLACKED-OUT, LIFTED FORD F-150 TRUCK flies into a red z parks. Big Nick hops out, pulls on a Blazer, slides on a of Von Zipper shades, pops a stick of gum in his mouth, a saunters toward a CRIME SCENE. At Randy’s donut shop. Slips underneath sawhorses and yellow “police line, do no cross” tape. He’s stopped by a hyper-vigilant GARDENA COP

dialogues.speaker: GARDENA COP
dialogues.text: Hey, big guy, this is-

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: - guy? Nick stops dead. Glares at the young copper. Flashes a SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT BADGE in his face. BIG NICK IS A COP

dialogues.speaker: GARDENA COP
dialogues.text: Sorry, lieutenant. It’s cool. It’s cool? Nick just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: No not cool. Go write a jay-walking ticket or something... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: 17 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 17.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mumbles ) ...Geeks. Nick has sobered himself up and shaken off the morning’s drama, almost on command. Comes from practice. Get the se here that yes, he’s a hard-charging wild-man. But he’s a charger at everything he does. Which in his line of work, means he’s good. Very. Nick surveys the hectic scene: ambulances, shell-casings everywhere, EMTs, the trashed SUV, BODIES OF THE DRIVER A MESSENGER lying on the ground in unnatural positions... He walks up to a GROUP OF MEN surrounding Outlaw#3, who l on the asphalt in a pool of his own blood.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That looks like it hurts... (nods to the men) Good morning, fellow officers. All the guys in the group nod and mumble monosyllabic greetings in unison, annoyed they are up this early. BIG NICK (CONT’D) All bright-eyed and bushy-tailed, I see. These are THE REGULATORS. Big Nick’s crew. LOS ANGELES SHERIFF DEPARTMENT’S METRO ROBBERY-HOMICIDE detail. A sub division within the department that operates with impunit A gang with badges. They've got their own tattoos, hand signs, everything. It’s a very, very fine line that separates these guys from the gangsters they take down. “Dragnet” they are not. Meet them: GUS HENDRIX, 33, an OG from Long Beach who always smells and dresses incredibly well. But beneath the gorgeous sui an aggressive, genetic freak who long ago mastered the ar intimidation on the mean streets of South Los. MURPHY “MURPH” CONNORS, 48, the salty dog here. A big, po marked Irishman from Oxnard sporting sweats, and a silk s with a Roman Emperor theme. He’s terrified of the water a has never surfed a day in his life, despite the fact that grew up across the street from the beach. He stuck to spo that are played indoors, like boxing, which explains the angle of his nose, and drinking, which explains his hango BENNY “BORRACHO” MEGALLON, 40, a no-bullshit veterano fro East Los who has a serious drinking problem, gambling problem, women problem...Name the vice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And “TONY Z” ZAPATA, 38, an irreverent, dry-witted pussy- hound from the Valley who’s good looks and better humor b a driven, tough, focused cop. Outlaw#3 moans slightly. He’s still alive, barely. His fa is drained of almost all color, the gaping wound in his g having bled out profusely. BIG NICK (CONT’D) I take it he’s a bad guy?

dialogues.text: You mean the guy with the black body armor, machine-gun and gas mask?

dialogues.text: OTFL. We know who he is yet?

dialogues.text: (Murph shakes his head) Rough night?

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Yes. Next subject.

dialogues.text: You're not lookin’ so hot there, bubba. Nick lifts his sunglasses. They see his banged up face.

dialogues.speaker: TONY Z
dialogues.text: I think he looks amazing.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: I got enough toxins in me to turn the Gaza Strip into a gay pride parade.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK

dialogues.speaker: GUS

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: (to Outlaw#3) How you feeling there, champ? Not to good? Want a medic? I’1l make you a deal. You tell me the names of all the bad guys that got away, and I’1l get you a medic.

dialogues.speaker: OUTLAW
dialogues.text: (mumbles through bloody teeth) ...I’m not a punk. Cop faggots... Nick glances over at the dead bodies of the Brinks men, l back to Outlaw#3, checks his pulse. He’s still alive. Bar An EMT hurries toward them to assist. Nick and the others share a look. THEY WAVE OFF THE EMT.

dialogues.speaker: EMT
dialogues.text: Officer, would you please step aside-

dialogues.speaker: MURPH

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 meters down the boulevard, a safe distance away, a nondescript Mazda pulls to the curb, Bosco at the wheel. Bosco looks thru a DIGITAL NIKON CAMERA, zooms in on the donut shop. The motor-drive whirs as HE DOCUMENTS THE CRI SCENE, then disappears back into morning traffic. ON BIG NICK AND THE REGULATORS -- Nick picks up a spent s casing, inspects it, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Tungsten carbide. Jacketed. That’s no joke.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (motions to the 2 downed Gardena PD across the street) Cut through their vests like butter.

dialogues.text: Ambushed’em while they were picking up breakfast. Surrounded the truck, Brinks Driver tried to do what he’s paid to do. The tungsten rounds went straight through the windshield, took him out. They took off with the truck. Gardena PD lost them under Hawthorne Municipal.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: They knew the route. Picked it because it’s right next to the Municipal airport, knew the restricted air space meant no ghetto bird air support. Smart... Talk to Brinks? How much they get away with?

dialogues.text: They were en route to a BofA pick up for a Fed drop...There was nothing in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Nothing in the truck? (They all shake their heads) They stole a fucking empty armored car? (pause) Why the fireworks? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK

BIG NICK (CONT’D) Lift prints, see who he rolls with. A Crown Vic pulls up, and 3 MEN step out. Nice new haircu bad suits, freshly shaven. THE FEDS, LA BANK SQUAD. A collective grunt and sigh from our boys.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t deal with this retard factory right now. Can one of you handle it? (They all play dumb, look away ) All right... Witnesses? Donut shop guy? Any video surveillance? Talk to DOT?

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Pull it all together, meet at the office. Gus and The Regulators nod, leave the scene as “LOBBIN’ B GOLIGHTLY approaches. Fed, 45, stick up his ass. Not a ha out of place on his head, not a stone left unturned in hi cases. A cowboy’s, like Nick, worst nightmare.

dialogues.text: “Lobbin Bob.” How’s that mean tennis game? No response. Nick imitates a forehand swing. Nick looks B up and down, gives him a thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: BOB

dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear that... What’re you doing here anyway? No legal tender was stolen. It isn’t federal.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: You pausing for dramatic effect?

dialogues.speaker: BOB

Whittier.” The REGULATORS huddle around their desks, which are cover in a maelstrom of take-out and “CRIME BOOKS” -- THICK 3-R BINDER NOTEBOOKS, each one dedicated to another crime cre “ROGUE'S GALLERY” of SUSPECT SURVEILLANCE PHOTOS cover th walls. Nick holds court, while eating his donuts:

dialogues.text: Who’s running this crew? Who’s “The Head”? Nick taps a suspect “photo” tacked to the wall that has n photograph, only THE OUTLINE OF A MAN’S HEAD WITH A BIG QUESTION MARK IN THE MIDDLE -- “The Head”.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why steal an Armored with nothing in it?

dialogues.text: But where? Brinks carrier? The casino? BofA? The Fed? Fuckin’ donut shop? Who?

dialogues.speaker: TONY Z
dialogues.text: Merrimen.

dialogues.text: Armored cars? And empty ones? Maybe... whoever it is, heists are an addiction. They're thrill bandits, they don’t do it for the money. They do it for the rush. The sound of gunfire. The getaway. All of it... Soon enough, they'll need their fix. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Tony Z) We still got a tail on that FNG his crew was hanging with? That Alison kid? Tony Z nods. Yes, they do. INT. BAR, “THE HOFBRAU” - NIGHT 20 One of those joints you walk into and say, “if you put th in a movie, nobody would believe it existed.” David Lynch peyote couldn’t dream up this place. But here it is... “THE HOFBRAU”. An old Mexican cowboy, contrabandista haun that’s been bought by a German family and is in the proce of being transformed into a biergarten. It’s cavernous, w dark, red-lit booths in the corners. Two mannequins are featured in the foyer, the “man” dressed like a gun-sling Mariachi, the “woman” like a Bavarian St.Pauli girl. And clientele is every bit as eclectic as the decor -- the pl is crawling with OFF-DUTY COPS, parolees, convicts, cholo with Raider jerseys, HIGH-END CROOKS. They come here to k an ear to the street, plot out scores, and get very loade COME IN ON the BARTENDER. IT’S DONNIE, from Merrimen’s cr Whether they be regulars, or here for the second time, th customers marvel at DONNIE’S SAVANT-LIKE ABILITY TO KNOW THEIR ORDER AND THEIR NAME. And he gets it right every ti A Brazilian soccer match plays on a satellite-fed TV, wat by an old drunk, WOLFGANG, languishing at the bar. Wolfga holds up a finger. Donnie serves him a Beck’s, when Wolfg aggressively grabs onto Donnie’s arm:

dialogues.speaker: WOLFGANG
dialogues.text: If it vasn’t for the Vinter of ‘44, they'd be trinking Beck’s in Moscow. Wolfgang raises his eyebrows, lifts his Beck’s proudly.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You learn something every day... Last call, Wolfgang. There’s a fundamental sadness that informs every aspect o Donnie’s being. He’s handsome, witty and sharp, but he’s definitely experienced failure. He’s now too old to hope, too young to have resigned himself to his station in life Donnie turns to some regulars at the bar -- a group of cool, blue-collar guys that make everybody laugh. There’s MACK, black, wearing a VERIZON uniform. BAS, 41, Armenian wearing a blue “Waste Management" jumpsuit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 25.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As is ALEXI, 33, a Brazilian with cauliflower ears and a stoned, infectious smile.

dialogues.text: How the hell you remember everybody’s order like that? I can’t even remember what year I was born.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Gotta be good at something, I guess. Donnie cracks a beer for himself. They all toast:

dialogues.speaker: BAS
dialogues.text: To money and women.

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: That we don’t have. A man whistles at Donnie from behind the bar. The bar's owner, “ZIGGY” ZERHUSEN, 68. Ziggy’s a striking looking m tall, lanky limbs of a former athlete, full head of gray hair, deep-set eyes, tanned skin, mouthful of chicklets- shaped teeth. And one of those tempers that comes from surviving the hard years... Ziggy motions impatiently for Donnie to cut it off.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: You guys are outta here. Gotta close up. A grumbling chorus of “see you later Donnie” as patrons l -- the guys, uniformed cops, some shady OGs, Wolfgang. Wolfgang left something on the bar -- an ID TAG. Donnie s that Wolfgang is gone. He SLIPS THE ID TAG INTO HIS POCKE Donnie approaches the end of the bar where one last patro sits. He scoops up the $10 bill left there.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: That's for you, Fraulein. Fraulein? Donnie looks up -- the generous tipper is BIG N

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donnie doesn’t really want to talk to this joker. Was kin looking forward to cleaning up and just going home, but..

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: All the time. This is their spot.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: There’re some shady cats in here. This is the last place I’d think they'd be.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s always been one of those places where everybody goes, you know? Neutral grounds. “Rick’s” in Casablanca. Nick notices a small SIGN behind the bar that reads, “Loo lips sink ships”, and a TEAM PHOTO of a SOCCER TEAM.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: A den of thieves. You must’ve heard some stories in here.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Put a few drinks in a man, a nice steak on his plate, couple women walking around...he’ll tell you he shot Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Ain't that the truth. Nick finishes his beer, sets it on the bar, heads out.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: See you later.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Look forward to it. Donnie eyes the big bald dude as he walks out. What was t all about? He grabs Nick’s beer, throws it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks toward a primer-grey ‘72 Z28 parked there. Quiet and desolate at this hour. His footsteps echo in th cavernous structure. Comes to his car, pulls out his keys unlocks it. A sense of dread washes over him. But he does know why. Looks around the garage. Few parked cars. But there’s no one around. He hops in his car. Shuts the door. Hand-cranks the windo down, turns over the ignition. The sublime throaty roar o the supercharged V8 454 rumbles to life. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 22 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He feathers the throttle a couple times, warming up the engine. In the way that he handles the vehicle, the train eye will recognize, Donnie knows how to drive. As he drops the transmission into reverse, A PAIR OF HEADLIGHTS appear behind him. Donnie looks to his rearvie A TRUCK HAS PULLED UP RIGHT BEHIND HIM, BLOCKING HIM IN. truck’s BRIGHTS are on. Footsteps. Donnie tenses, looks back. A man approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Fraulein? Donnie squints his eyes. It’s the dude from the bar. BIG NICK.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah? Next thing he knows, a BOLT OF ELECTRICITY is bouncing in face. Then it zaps him. Donnie convulses violently, then a fist clips his jaw. Hi body goes limp, head collapses into the dash. BLACK SCREEN. A TITLE reads, “Donnie.”

dialogues.text: EYES flutter. Slowly open. Donnie awakens. Looks around -- he’s in a bedroom. A mote bedroom. Shitty one. Stained sheets. Naked bulb overhead. Donnie’s lying on the bed. There’s nobody in the room. He no clue where he is. He feels the sheets. They’re wet. He sits up. HE’S NAKED.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Ho! He scrambles around, desperately searching for his clothe SOUND. A TOILET FLUSHING. Followed by some giggles. His e go to a bathroom door. Sounds came from in there. The door swings open. Big Nick and a BLOND WOMAN stumble out. He’s zipping up his pants. She’s wiping her mouth an nose. Donnie FREEZES.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Fraulein! You're up! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Donnie covers his privates.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: In the bathroom. Big Nick and the Blond open a door to another room, exit. Donnie quickly moves for the bathroom. His clothes hang o the tub. Puts them on. A big yellow ring is stained on hi pants. They’re damp still. He cringes. He looks to see if Nick is near. No one. He quickly opens bathroom window. Tries to climb out. BARS. Blocking the w He searches for another way out. Windows over the bed. He pulls back the curtains. BARS AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Shit. The only way out is through the door Nick went through. SOUNDS. More giggles from the other room. His heart pound He rubs his eyes, takes a deep breath. Trying to get a gr

dialogues.text: Donnie peeks his head in the seedy motel living room. His eyes widen slightly. The Regulators. All of them. Engaged in activities unbeco of an officer -- drinking, smoking, and whatever else. Gu Tony Z, and Borracho are counting money. Murph cracks ope and inspects what looks to be a brick of coke. A few gold plated handguns are piled on the table. Looks like they robbed a drug dealer. What Donnie finds particularly interesting is the fact that they all have BADGES hanging from their necks. A Barry White groove drifts in from another room. From wh a few TRICKS come and go.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Look what the cat dragged in. Whassup gangsta?! Have a seat. Donnie hesitates. Gus pulls out a chair for him.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Donnie sits. Murph plops a huge chrome-plated SIG .45 on table, kicks his feet up.

dialogues.text: Um...it’s all right. I’m sorry. You might have me confused with somebody else. I-

dialogues.text: Ah...I’m good.

dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MURPH
dialogues.text: Then why not? Donnie gets a glimpse outside. Sees a parking lot and neo signs. He’s in a motel. That much he knows.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Can somebody just tell me why my clothes were off? Nick sits down, amused with himself. Raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Is your hole sore? (Donnie’s eyes flutter) ..-Well? Is it? Donnie can’t even respond. Big Nick slaps his shoulder. H BIG NICK (CONT’D) I’m just fucking with you, bubba! You pissed in your pants. I had one of the girls clean you up. All good. The Bad Lieutenants cackle. A wave of relief washes over (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 30.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: I really think you’re mistaking me for someone. I have to be honest - Nick throws an 8X10 SURVEILLANCE PHOTO in front of Donnie Donnie looks -- IT’S HIM. NEXT TO MERRIMEN ON A CITY STRE

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: - what were you saying? Honest something? (Got him. Donnie says nothing) We’re not mistaking you for anybody.

dialogues.text: So you did a stint at County for attempted manslaughter -- fastest speeding ticket in California history. Nice.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ genius. How fast were you going?
They all react -- “oohh, damn nigga, puta madre”.

dialogues.text: What did you say to the cop who pulled you over? What reason did you give?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: (points at Donnie) I like him. His pecker’s no bigger than a button on a fur coat, sad to see, but I like him. Me gusta!

dialogues.speaker: GUS

And some of them niggas got gaspumps. Now personally speaking, that just don’t sound like that much fun. I don’t know, you tell me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 31.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: ...I know the guy from the bar. He comes in-

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: - bullshit... Look. Nick rolls up his sleeve, shows Donnie a TAT BLASTED ONTO FOREARM. It’s of a skull with a toothy grimace, and glowi eyes. A bandana is wrapped around the forehead, the word “Regulator” stitched into it. One bony hand clasps a smok revolver, the other a “dead man’s hand” -- ace and an eig BIG NICK (CONT’D) Do you know what this means? It means I am member of a clique.

dialogues.speaker: TONY Z
dialogues.text: Sorta like a gang.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Sorta. Only we have badges. Which means... (Nick leans forward) You. Are. Done.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: He ain’t lying.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this. Do we look like the types who'll arrest you, put on handcuffs? (starts sing-songing the words ) .»--and book you down at the station, and type up paperwork, and build our case, and put on a suit for court... Nick looks to Donnie for conformation. Donnie shakes his head. BIG NICK (CONT’D) No. Exactly. Thank you. We just shoot you. So tell me, what the fuck are you doing in that crew? I mean, look at you dude. Those dudes are bad dudes. Ex military, great thieves, but straight convicts.... What’s Merrimen doing drinking beers with you for? Talk shop? Is he gonna hit the fuckin’ Hofbrau, and you're his inside guy? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Look, I swear to God. I know nothing. I met—

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: - stop. Just...shut up. Nick shuts his eyes, takes a deep breath, sighs. He’s thinking. BIG NICK (CONT’D) (to Tony Z) Where’s Chaminade? (Tony Z motions to back room) Chaminade! A black hooker saunters in. CHAMINADE -- straight up ho. pumps. Huge, sloppy fake rack. Big hair. Gnarly. BIG NICK (CONT’D) Chaminade. This is our friend Donnie. Donnie, meet Chaminade. dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Now listen to me, fuck face. We don’t give a shit about you. But rest assured, she will bite your pecker clean off, because she can’t fuckin’ stand whiteboys, and nothing would make her happier... unless you rat for us, you will be missing an appendage. You decide. Donnie nods over and over. His face is beet red.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE

If cops come down on us, he wants everyone in the dark, so we can’t tell you guys anything. I’1l take a polygraph, whatever, but I’m telling you, that’s all you'll ever get from me, cause that’s all I know.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: (golf claps, impressed) That was relatively convincing. Good stuff... When did you meet him? Donnie rubs his eyes. Is this real?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Your freedom, for one. Two... (thinks on how to put it) ...You’re not the bad guys, bro. (directly at Donnie, no bullshit) We are. Donnie gets it. There’s no choice, really.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: ...few months ago, this guy came in the bar a few times, and, you know, I got to know him a little bit. Like everybody else, once he had a couple drinks, he started talking...  24 25 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie tending bar. Bosco’s there, putting down the Cuba

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -..What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not sure. Bosco was his handle. Big white dude. Yoked up, arms are sleeved. He talked about being in the military for some time. Worked for the DWP. We hit it off because we both grew up in So Cal. Liked cars. Bosco sips his Cuba Libre, looks around. He leans forward

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He asked me if I was interested in making a little extra cash. Said they had a job for me, “a cherry that was ripe for picking”.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who's “they”? Bosco writes something down on a napkin, slides it to Don

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-Merrimen. “POMONA MINING CO.” RESTAURANT, POMONA - DAY 25 Merrimen sits in a booth overlooking the 10. Bosco stands

dialogues.speaker: BOSCO
dialogues.text: -.-my boy did time with him at Wayside. He’s cool. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 26 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Merrimen glances over at Donnie, who waits nervously 30 f away. Merrimen finally nods at Bosco. Bosco waves Donnie over, introduces them. They shake hands. Donnie sits across from Merrimen. Merri glances at Bosco. Bosco takes the cue, leaving them alone

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where'd you meet him? Merrimen and Donnie converse quietly.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some restaurant way east off the 10. All he told me was he might have some extra work. Kept everything real low-key. Struck me as a very meticulous, sharp guy. He was feeling me out, putting together a crew. He had just gotten out, from what I understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy Lump Lump sits before us, smoking the same cig he w when we first met him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LUMP LUMP
dialogues.text: So what you gonna do out there?

dialogues.speaker: FROM HIM ON A COT, IS HIS CELLIE, MERRIMEN.
dialogues.text: Merrimen buttons up his prison-issued flannel, ties his prison-issued “Bruce Lee” shoes. Gathers his few belongin books, drawings, letters -- into a shoe-box.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Bang my old lady, play it cool...lay low. A title reads, “Feb. 9, 2011. Federal Correctional Instit Terminal Island.”

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LUMP LUMP

And the door to the cell is buzzed open. The FCI Cop ente picks up Merrimen’s shoe-box of belongings.

dialogues.text: (coughs ) .+-quite the contrary. He ain’t lying. The FCI Cops laugh, grab Merrimen by the lead him out. Merrimen pauses at the cell door, looks to Willy:

dialogues.text: You never told me which rule you broke. Willy meets Merrimen’s gaze, raises his eyebrows:

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LUMP LUMP

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: No you won't. Willy laughs out loud. The cell door shuts, locks Willy inside. Merrimen peers through the door. He and Willie sh a final moment. Then Merrimen is led back to freedom. STAY ON WILLY, now alone in his cell, smoking his cig. He exhales, long and slow...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LUMP LUMP
dialogues.text: That’s what they all say.... He stamps out his cig, lies on his cot, and shuts his eye

dialogues.text: Merrimen is buzzed out of the prison’s front gate. He ste outside into the hazy sun, a free man. Standing there in the parking lot waiting for him, is his lady. HOLLY. 30, white, stripper hot. She leans against t Suburban, bubbling over with nervous excitement. She’s dressed provocatively, her tits on display. Merrimen walks toward her like he’s crossing a minefield. squints his eyes, the sunlight painful. Holly tears up as they meet, and embrace. It’s a touching albeit awkward moment. Because it never lives up to promi She kisses him, looks him over. His skin is so white, it looks grey.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You look great, baby. They both know he looks like shit. He’s hesitant, distant uncomfortable. But he manages a smile.

dialogues.text: Holly drives. Merrimen rides along, staring out the windo the passing cars, streets, people, a mixture of fascinati and fear in his eyes. Holly's iPhone vibrates, startling him. He looks at the device suspiciously.

dialogues.text: Is that a phone? Holly giggles, thrilled that he spoke.

dialogues.text: Yeah. My cell-phone. She holds it up for him to see. He nods, looks back out t window. Squints his eyes again.

Goosebumps run down his arms. His eyes l onto it as they drive past... EXT./INT. ENSON’S HOUSE, GARAGE DOJO - DAY 29 Carson. Near the Port of LA. Tidy, lower-middle class neighborhoods, home to longshoremen, mechanics, and gangsters. Power-lines crisscross overhead. GOODYEAR BLIM floats nearby. Bosco’s Chevy K5 pulls up to a cul-de-sac. Donnie rides shotgun. They park before a remodeled home on a double-lo with tiki-torches out front. The garage is open. Inside, Merrimen, Enson and his SAMOA MAFIA BROTHERS work out in the GARAGE DOJO, doing prison burpees and popping heavy bags. Posters of Bruce Lee, Ali Sonny Garcia, BJ Penn, and Manny Pacquiao cover the walls Bosco and Donnie walk up. The reception is cool. The wolf nods to Bosco, eyeballs Donnie. As is their custom.

dialogues.text: (to Bosco) Food’s out back. Bosco nods, knows the drill. They’re gonna put Donnie on sniff him out a while. Donnie follows Bosco thru the gara EXT. ENSON’S HOUSE, BACKYARD - DAY 30 Big yard with a pool, fire pit, open grill and sport cour ENSON’S 5 “hapa” KIDS, ages 3 to 15, hop in and out of th pool, dive-bomb the water slide, gun footballs. His Filip wife, MALIA, smokes with Merrimen’s woman, Holly, and 2 o ATTRACTIVE DANCERS who sun themselves poolside in thongs. Meat sizzles on the grill. And man we recognize as Outlaw MARSHALL RHODES, 44, tends to it. (CONTINUED)

Merrimen, Enson and his Bros finish their workout, join t rest out back. Merrimen helps himself to a big bloody ste sits near Donnie. Eats. As do the Samoans. Nobody says mu The vibe makes Donnie sweat. He busies himself with his f Every once in a while, Enson or Marshall will say somethi quietly to Merrimen. Enson’s oldest, a precocious 15 year old girl, MALOA, sit the edge of the pool, lightly splashing her feet in the water. She’s looking at Donnie. Donnie and she make brief contact. She smiles, alluring beyond her years. Donnie immediately averts his eyes. Enson approaches Donnie, offers him a Primo. He takes it. Enson sits with he and Merrimen. Donnie shifts again. Not that while they offered him beer, he’s the only one drink it. Merrimen, Enson, they all drink water.

dialogues.text: .--blend in. Cops don’t see you. Donnie looks around the place, nods.

dialogues.text: +-.-I can do that. Donnie “zwischen gas” downshifts into second, then squeez the throttle. The Saleen’s 400 hps roar. Donnie goes into turns at 100+ mph, hitting apexs, heel-toe downshifting, trailing the brakes. Donnie can drive. Donnie hits a blind turn too fast. The car begins to oversteer. Merrimen holds on tight, braces. Donnie turns it and guns it, pulls out of the drift expertly. Merrimen tries to play it cool, but he’s shitting bricks. Donnie slows, slips it into neutral, lets the engine cool car coast as the brakes, clutch, and tires steam. Merrime turns to Donnie, looks at him much differently now.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that what you need?

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: «.+-something like that. Donnie slips it into gear. Drives easy.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: Drive away like a 16 year old trying to pass her first driver’s license test?

dialogues.text: (chuckles, nods) .+-Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: «..You got some balls, bro. Donnie’s ego swells. Feels good. This outlaw life.

dialogues.text: Donnie waits behind the wheel of a SUBURBAN, parked in a dock, engine idling, nervously tapping the dash. Few vans and work trucks in the subterranean garage. Muffled SOUND OF LIVE ELECTRONICA MUSIC and the audience’s cheers can b heard.

dialogues.text: Donnie’s eyes are locked on the rear-view mirror and the LOADING DOCK AREA behind him. Finally, MEN emerge rolling MONEY TUBS (plexi-glass boxes of cash on wheels), lift th into the back of the Suburban. Merrimen’s crew jumps in. Donnie takes off. INT. “PACIFIC HORIZON FREIGHT” 3PL WAREHOUSE - DAY 35 The crew unloads the tubs, handling them with surgical gloves. Spread out on tables in organized rows, Enson catalogues the crew’s “ROBBERY KIT” -- assault rifles, black ski-masks with smiley faces, gas-masks, body armor, police scanners, stopwatches, several sets of California license plates, zip-ties, flares, spray-on hair coloring, hairpieces, 30 sunglasses, and 3,000 rounds of ammo in various calibers... Merrimen inspects the goods -- DEPOSIT SLIPS FOR THE “FED RESERVE BANK, LOS ANGELES BRANCH.”

dialogues.speaker: BOSCO
dialogues.text: Is the count right? Merrimen nods, looks at Donnie who paces, amped from the rush.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: Feels good huh? Donnie meets Merrimen’s gaze, unsure. Then he nods. Yes i does. Bosco looks into the tub. STACK AFTER STACK OF BUNDLED $1 DOLLAR NOTES. He sighs:

dialogues.speaker: BOSCO
dialogues.text: Sure we shouldn’t just call it the day? That's alot of money right there.

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN
dialogues.text: You want 1.2 in bait bills? Spend the rest of your life looking over your shoulder? Or do you want 20? Clean.... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERRIMEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (regards the fruit of their labor) Don’t touch it. We’re trading up.

dialogues.text: BACK TO THE PRESENT. Donnie sits with Nick.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Trading up to what?

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: He’s planning something. Big. What, I have no idea... I’m out of the loop. They never speak. Any of them. They’re always quiet.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: People with things to hide never have much to say. Nick just stares at Donnie.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: -+--am I under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. You just keep doing your thing. We’ll see you around. Donnie pauses, unsure, doesn’t understand -

dialogues.speaker: BIG NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - get the fuck out of here. So Donnie stands, and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie looks around. By the looks of the denizens lurking around this joint, he’s deep in the ‘hood somewhere. He heads out onto the street, spots Tony Z and Gus sharin laugh with Chaminade by her car. Only now, Chaminade is n longer Chaminade. CHAMINADE IS A COP. She pulls the “toothless” mouthpiece out of her mouth, th bitches and moans at her colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 38 39 40 Den of Thieves February 6, 2016 Draft 44,

dialogues.text: Come on hon, you’re a trooper!

dialogues.speaker: CHAMINADE
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah. You tell my husband, he’11l file for divorce. And I’1l beat your ass! Tony Z and Gus fold over with laughter. They all say good night as Chaminade drives off and heads home. Donnie’s been had. Feels like an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie walks to the corner of La Brea and Venice blvd. He gets his bearings, waits at a RTD BUS-STOP. The BUS arrives. Door opens. Head low, Donnie gets on the bus. And rides it home. INT. DONNIE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 39 Donnie dumps some take-out on a plate, eats, then remembe something. Searches his pockets. Finds WOLFGANG’S DISCARD ID CARD, from the bar. He opens a shoebox FILLED WITH DOZ OF SIMILAR IDS. Drops Wolfgang’s card inside. Shuts the b Place is rather spartan. Yet some curious items lie about laptop. Binoculars. A tripod. Camera equipment. Passports Tony Robbins, other “personal power” and “Self Made Millionaire” books and DVDs. And a dense MANUAL that read front, “HOLZWERK GMACH”. He looks out the window, over the low rooftops of LA, the of vapor lights, power lines, telephone poles. Somewhere the distance, SIRENS wail, and DOGS bark. He collapses in bed, feels the swelling on his head. Donn shuts his eyes. Tries to block out the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CELL PHONE VIBRATES. Donnie’s eyes snap open. Hasn’t mo since last night, wears the same clothes. He answers, gro

dialogues.speaker: BOSCO
dialogues.text: (over phone) Peckerwood. Be at the Hofbrau in 25.

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE
dialogues.text: (clears his throat) -..25 minutes? (CONTINUED)
